column4: I don't believe you can use disk identifier. You need to identify individual partitions within the disk anyway, not the entire disk....
no kidding...
what do you suggest to guarantee the order in which my devices get mounted?
to be absolutely certain of the mount order, you need to list the mount commands one after another in /etc/rc.local. Why is the mount order so important to you?
because given two disks, A and B, sometimes A contains the content of B and viceversa
I'm not sure what you mean by "sometimes A contains the content of B and viceversa". Do you mean the disks get mounted to the wrong directories sometimes? You can prevent that by using UUIDs...
that's right. How do I find the UUID of my external devices?
or to be more precise, the UUID of the partitions within my external drives?
connect the devices and then run sudo blkid and paste the output into a file...
